articles.headline: U.S. Charges Russian Intelligence Officers in Major Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: Prosecutors said the suspects hacked elections in France, the electricity grid in Ukraine and the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors said the suspects hacked elections in France, the electricity grid in Ukraine and the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Monday unsealed charges accusing six Russian military intelligence officers of an aggressive worldwide hacking campaign that caused mass disruption and cost billions of dollars by attacking targets like a French presidential election, the electricity grid in Ukraine and the opening ceremony of the 2018 Winter Olympics.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Oil Industry Turns to Mergers and Acquisitions to Survive
articles.snippet: With the price of a barrel stuck around $40 and no recovery in sight, companies are combining to cut costs and ride out the pandemic.
articles.abstract: With the price of a barrel stuck around $40 and no recovery in sight, companies are combining to cut costs and ride out the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The once mighty oil and gas industry is flailing, desperately trying to survive a pandemic that has sharply reduced demand for its products.

articles.headline: Republican Voters Take a Radical Conspiracy Theory Mainstream
articles.snippet: QAnon, with encouragement from the president himself, has moved from online message boards to political rallies and congressional campaigns.
articles.abstract: QAnon, with encouragement from the president himself, has moved from online message boards to political rallies and congressional campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALTON, Ga. — Sitting in the local Republican office most days is a lifelong conservative named Diane Putnam, who got her first taste of politics when Dwight D. Eisenhower was president and she was a little girl telling people that she liked Ike.

articles.headline: U.S. Diplomats and Spies Battle Trump Administration Over Suspected Attacks
articles.snippet: American officials in China, Cuba and Russia say U.S. agencies are concealing the true extent of the episodes, leaving colleagues vulnerable to hostile actions abroad.
articles.abstract: American officials in China, Cuba and Russia say U.S. agencies are concealing the true extent of the episodes, leaving colleagues vulnerable to hostile actions abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The strange sound came at night: a crack like a marble striking the floor of the apartment above them.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Trump Calls Fauci ‘a Disaster’ and Shrugs Off Virus as Infections Soar
articles.snippet: With two weeks remaining in his re-election campaign, President Trump made the coronavirus his message and Dr. Anthony S. Fauci his foil, dismissing scientific advisers as “these idiots.”
articles.abstract: With two weeks remaining in his re-election campaign, President Trump made the coronavirus his message and Dr. Anthony S. Fauci his foil, dismissing scientific advisers as “these idiots.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump attacked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci as “a disaster” on Monday and said, despite signs that the nation was headed toward another coronavirus peak, that people were “tired” of hearing about the virus from “these idiots” in the government.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Maggie Haberman and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Voters Prefer Biden Over Trump on Almost All Major Issues, Poll Shows
articles.snippet: Joe Biden leads President Trump, 50 percent to 41 percent, a New York Times/Siena College poll shows, with voters favoring him by wide margins on the coronavirus and law and order.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden leads President Trump, 50 percent to 41 percent, a New York Times/Siena College poll shows, with voters favoring him by wide margins on the coronavirus and law and order.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: When Start-Ups Go Into the Garage (or Sometimes the Living Room)
articles.snippet: Labs closed in the pandemic, but innovation doesn’t stop. So while some workers have the home office, engineers have the garage.
articles.abstract: Labs closed in the pandemic, but innovation doesn’t stop. So while some workers have the home office, engineers have the garage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the folksiest of Silicon Valley origin stories: Tech start-up makes it big after a wide-eyed entrepreneur builds a prototype in his garage. But Colin Wessells could never have imagined that a pandemic would force him back into the garage just to keep his company going.

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Google of Illegally Protecting Monopoly
articles.snippet: A victory for the government could remake one of America’s most recognizable companies and the internet economy that it has helped define.
articles.abstract: A victory for the government could remake one of America’s most recognizable companies and the internet economy that it has helped define.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department accused Google on Tuesday of illegally protecting its monopoly over search and search advertising, the government’s most significant challenge to a tech company’s market power in a generation and one that could reshape the way consumers use the internet.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Apple iPhone 12 Review: Superfast Speed, if You Can Find It
articles.snippet: The new iPhone has an improved design, but it’s undermined by the wireless industry’s messy rollout of ultrafast 5G networks.
articles.abstract: The new iPhone has an improved design, but it’s undermined by the wireless industry’s messy rollout of ultrafast 5G networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: I started this iPhone review in the most peculiar way: by opening a map to find out where I could test it.

articles.headline: It’s Google’s World. We Just Live in It.
articles.snippet: Googling something was all we once did with Google. Now we spend hours a day using its maps, videos, security cameras, email, smartphones and more.
articles.abstract: Googling something was all we once did with Google. Now we spend hours a day using its maps, videos, security cameras, email, smartphones and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 20 years ago, I typed Google.com into my web browser for the first time. It loaded a search bar and buttons. I punched in “D.M.V. sample test,” scrolled through the results and clicked on a site.
